stream_context.summary: Kaze fixes an out-of-memory crash, reflects on weeks of heavy refactoring to remove nearly all vanilla Mario 64 actor code, and then spends most of the stream redesigning how the overworld gates access to “Part 8” (Bowser-themed area) without overwhelming players. He prototypes a new progression idea that uses a comedic NPC barrier (sleepy Bob-omb + “son” launcher) to send the player into a required side level tied to cap progression, while also exploring a dark, dynamic-light cave concept that requires hex-like tessellation for good vertex-lit falloff. Late in the stream he begins cleaning up the decomp’s course/stage tables to support adding new side levels, briefly breaking star counts and deciding to revisit later.
stream_context.significance_reason: Major technical milestone is reached/claimed (nearly all original SM64 actor code removed after weeks of refactors), alongside a concrete new overworld progression plan for Part 8 that ties gating to a side level and cap progression; plus early infrastructure work to add new courses/side levels (course tables/EEP bytes) that exposes fragility in the current setup.

findings.summary: Kaze says he spent the last few weeks refactoring and has removed almost all original Mario 64 actor code from the project; only a few remain (Chain Chomp, Pokey, Whirlpool), with plans to replace them too (custom Whirlpool after Ice Cap rework; Pokey is too buggy; Chain Chomp case is specific to a “zoo” use).
findings.quote: You have no idea how much time I spent in the last few weeks refactoring stuff… with that, all actor code in R64 is removed from the game.

findings.summary: He fixed a “safe block” crash that turned out to be an out-of-memory issue.

He rethinks the planned method for opening Overworld Part 8: the prior idea (finding underwater tunnels, breaking something underground to open a path elsewhere) now feels unintuitive and likely to overwhelm players who fully explore early.

A core pacing principle is stated: he does not want the player to unlock too many overworld branches at once; opening three levels simultaneously feels overwhelming, and he prefers one (or at most two) new directions at a time.
findings.quote: I don’t want the player to get to every overworld part at once… one or two is the absolute most we can do, otherwise it’s going to be overwhelming.

findings.summary: He shifts toward gating Part 8 via an NPC/minion encounter (Bowser-park “guard”) that can optionally route the player into a side level to earn access, instead of using a coin/pay barrier (which he calls a last resort).
findings.quote: The pay barrier is the absolute last resort if you have no other idea.

findings.summary: A specific gating pitch emerges: a big sleepy Bob-omb blocks the way; after the player kicks/wakes him, he gets angry and calls his “son,” who launches Mario into a side level. Beating that side level becomes the requirement to enter Part 8.

The gating idea becomes strongly tied to cap progression: he proposes requiring a cap (initially Cloud Cap, then corrects to Wing Cap based on where it’s obtained) to complete the side level, making that cap the “key” to Part 8 access.

Kaze describes his workflow with Biobak: Kaze sketches a rough V1 concept and sends it; Biobak generally works with substantial creative freedom, often showing near-finished work rather than incremental updates, and Kaze rarely has to request reversions.

He explores a dark cave/mineshaft side-level concept built around dynamic lights and explains a constraint: to make per-vertex lighting look consistent, geometry needs fairly even vertex spacing (a hex-like tessellation). Cubic/square grids can cause uneven light falloff due to differing edge lengths.

He converges on a “Dampe-like” follow-the-light maze: the player follows a moving glow (likely a Boo) from node to node; the Boo stays just ahead/out of view, and a final room contains the Boo with a star inside. He considers poison gas or fail conditions to prevent lingering/stuck states.

While preparing to add/import new side levels, he discovers he hasn’t added new side levels/courses this way before and starts editing decomp tables (course name table, course defines, stage counts). He calls the existing approach hacky/unworkable and attempts cleanup before adding content.

His course-table edits unexpectedly change the star count in his save (10 down to 7), indicating fragility in course/stage definitions and/or save/EEP byte mapping; he undoes changes and decides to revisit later rather than risk corrupting progression.
When asked about Steam, Kaze says he might make a custom-IP version someday, implying openness to a non-Mario release path.
He states beta access can’t be bought/donated into because that would be illegal for him to do, suggesting he’s deliberately avoiding pay-to-access testing arrangements.

biobak.summary: Biobak participates in brainstorming the dark/maze side-level concept (escape-room framing, light sources, and a follow-a-glowing-entity structure) and Kaze explicitly waits for Biobak’s concept direction before proceeding with some layout details.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There will be so many secrets in this goddamn game.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while describing how underwater tunnels connect back to Overworld Part 1 and how secret stars and hidden transitions will be layered throughout the overworld.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: What is managing to keep working on this project for so long? I guess, what else would I do? What do you want me to do else?
memorable_quotes.context: A rare moment of candid self-reflection when chat asks about his long-term motivation and endurance on RTYI.

key_stories.title: Weeks of refactors culminate in (nearly) removing all SM64 actor code
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals he’s been refactoring heavily for weeks and is close to eliminating all vanilla Mario 64 actor behavior code from the project. This reframes RTYI as not just a content hack but a largely custom game running on an N64-era foundation.
key_stories.challenge: The project still contained legacy SM64 actor logic that limited control, caused bugs, and kept the hack feeling tethered to the original game’s implementation details.
key_stories.process: Kaze refactors actor systems and progressively replaces/removes original actors; he identifies remaining holdouts (Whirlpool, Pokey, Chain Chomp) and outlines replacement plans (custom Whirlpool after Ice Cap rework; remake buggy Pokey; Chain Chomp special-case).
key_stories.outcome: He claims the game is now basically free of SM64 actor code aside from Mario and minor Goomba pieces, positioning the project as ‘slowly getting’ to 100% custom code.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s basically all gone… and then we’re like 100% custom code.

key_stories.title: Redesigning how Overworld Part 8 opens to avoid overwhelming players
key_stories.summary: Kaze rejects an earlier plan to open Part 8 via an underwater tunnel action that changes a distant overworld path. He uses pacing and clarity as the primary criteria, trying to ensure players don’t unlock too many major areas at once.
key_stories.challenge: The old gating method felt unintuitive (doing something underground to affect a faraway overworld path) and likely to be discovered too early by thorough explorers, opening too much content at once.
key_stories.process: He evaluates multiple barrier types (star-count gate, NPC guard/minion, ‘pay toll’ which he dislikes, disguise idea he fears would be bad gameplay). He increasingly prefers an NPC-driven gate that routes the player into a purpose-built side level instead of a blunt resource wall.
key_stories.outcome: He tentatively commits to a simple, comedic NPC gate concept rather than the underwater-breakable-object plan, keeping Part 8 access controlled and legible.
key_stories.key_quote: We need simple stuff, stuff that’s straightforward.

key_stories.title: A comedic gate: sleepy Bob-omb launches you into a required cap-focused side level
key_stories.summary: The stream’s most concrete new design is a character gag that doubles as progression gating: a sleepy Bob-omb blocks the path, reacts to being kicked, and summons his ‘son’ to launch Mario into a side level. Completing that side level (potentially requiring the Wing/Cloud cap) becomes the key to entering Part 8.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needs a barrier that feels diegetic and fun, not a ‘paywall,’ and that doesn’t open multiple overworld branches too early.
key_stories.process: He builds the gag in steps: sleepy Bob-omb dialogue → player wake-up interaction → escalation (calls son) → forced transition (launched to side level). He then ties the side level to cap progression so the gate naturally enforces intended ability order.
key_stories.outcome: A clear blueprint emerges for implementing Part 8 gating while also giving the team a home for one of the planned side levels and reinforcing cap-based progression.
key_stories.key_quote: He’s like, I have an important job of going fucking back and forth for all eternity.

key_stories.title: Dynamic-light cave idea collides with geometry constraints (hex tessellation)
key_stories.summary: Kaze wants a dark cave/maze section where light and visibility are core mechanics, but explains that per-vertex lighting only looks good with evenly spaced vertices. This forces level geometry and art style decisions (hex-like tessellation, fewer cubes) and shapes the feasibility of the concept.
key_stories.challenge: Making a “very dark” level readable and atmospheric without ugly lighting artifacts or excessive complexity.
key_stories.process: He demonstrates how uneven edge lengths in square grids distort light falloff, experiments with alternative triangulations, considers scaling and adding a local light source around Mario, and debates how a ‘follow the glow’ maze could prevent players from getting stuck.
key_stories.outcome: He tentatively settles on a Dampe-like follow-a-glow structure (likely Boo-based) and accepts a “good enough” tessellation approach for testing, while postponing full pipeline decisions.
key_stories.key_quote: The gameplay is just atmosphere and vibes.

open_questions.topic: Final decision and implementation details for opening Overworld Part 8
open_questions.context: Kaze explores multiple gating methods (underwater-trigger, star-count Womp guard, NPC minion, pay barrier) and gravitates toward a sleepy Bob-omb that launches the player into a side level tied to cap progression.
questions: What made the underwater ‘break something below to open a path above’ idea finally cross the line from ‘cool secret’ to ‘bad pacing’—was it playtests, your own intuition, or feedback?
Did the sleepy Bob-omb + launcher side-level gate ship as described? If it changed, what replaced it and why?
How did you decide whether the gate should require Wing Cap vs Cloud Cap, and how did that tie into where each cap is earned in the overworld?
How do you ensure the gate doesn’t feel like a forced minigame (a complaint Kaze mentions about other 3D platformers) while still serving progression control?

open_questions.topic: Designing the dark ‘follow-the-glow’ maze without softlocks
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the Dampe-style maze concept (Boo/light always just ahead) but worries about players getting stuck, losing visibility, or the geometry/lighting constraints making it frustrating.
questions: What rule set did you land on to prevent players from getting stuck—did the guide entity reset, wait at nodes, or teleport forward/back under certain conditions?
Did you add fail pressure (poison gas/time) as discussed, and how did you balance atmosphere with fairness?
What did playtests show: did players find it tense-and-fun or confusing-and-annoying? What changed as a result?

open_questions.topic: Course/side-level infrastructure and the ‘star count dropped from 10 to 7’ incident
open_questions.context: While cleaning up decomp course/stage defines to support adding new side levels, Kaze accidentally altered star counts in his save and backed out to avoid breaking progression.
questions: What exactly caused the star count to change—was it course enum ordering, save/EEP byte mapping, level IDs, or something else?
After this scare, what was your final approach to safely adding new courses/side levels without corrupting saves?
Did this incident change how you version saves for testers or how you structure course IDs going forward?
